TextView.android:text: Lesson 6 serves as a ‘breather’ and doesn’t introduce any new shorthand principles. In this lesson, you will go through an Alphabet Review, a straightforward explanation of the rules for joining the strokes you’ve learned so far, a Recall Chart, and some Reading Practice.
1. Alphabet Review These are the 22 shorthand strokes you learned in Lessons 1 through 5. Can you read all of them in under 20 seconds?
For your interest, you might want to know the principles behind how the words you’ve learned are written. Take note of the groups that the joinings naturally form.
2. Circles are placed inside curves and outside angles.
3. Circles are drawn clockwise on a straight stroke or positioned between two straight strokes that run in the same direction.
4. When two curves are written in opposite directions, the circle is placed on the back of the first curve.
5. The ‘o’ hook is written on its side before n or m, unless it follows a downward stroke.
6. The oo hook is written on its side after n, m.
7. The under ith is used when it connects to o, r, or l; in all other cases, the over ith is applied.
